text: A data ecosystem consists of the data management activities and related data, infrastructure, tools, processes,
label: BODY

text: stakeholders and applicable guidance in a context. Understanding how the different components of a data
label: BODY

text: ecosystem relate to one another and how data moves within and between organizations helps to ensure that data
label: BODY

text: is managed in a responsible way.
label: BODY

text: There are three steps to understanding data ecosystems in a humanitarian response:
label: BODY

text: •	 Developing an organization-level data management registry and activity diagrams.
label: BODY

text: •	 Compiling registries at the cluster/sector-level and system-wide level.
label: BODY

text: This tip sheet offers instructions and templates for completing these steps in line with the IASC Operational
label: BODY

text: Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action.1
label: BODY

text: STEP 1: DEVELOPING AN ORGANIZATION-LEVEL DATA MANAGEMENT REGISTRY AND
label: HH1

text: The first step to understanding a data ecosystem is documenting each of the data management activities led
label: BODY

text: by your organization in the context. Examples of data management activities include needs assessments,
label: BODY

text: displacement tracking, beneficiary registration and enrollment, protection case management, community
label: BODY

text: perception surveys, and response monitoring and evaluation, among others.
label: BODY

text: Organizations should document these activities in a data management registry, which typically includes the
label: BODY

text: •	 Activity description, including type (e.g. registration, needs assessment, survey), purpose, location and
label: BODY

text: sensitivity of the data being managed.
label: BODY

text: •	 Timeframe and status, including whether the activity is one-off or recurring, and whether it is ongoing,
label: BODY

text: •	 Actors and responsibilities, including the lead actor, collaborators, roles, and relevant cluster and sub-
label: BODY

text: •	 Infrastructure and tools used for collecting, receiving, storing, analyzing and destroying the data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data disaggregation, such as by admin level, sex, age or disability, and if relevant, the methodology used.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data sharing, including the websites, reports and information products the data management activity will
label: BODY

text: •	 Guidance and governance, including Standard Operating Procedures for the activity, applicable legislation
label: BODY

text: and regulations, and applicable Information Sharing Protocols or similar documents.
label: BODY

text: 1  For reference see the IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: Use the Data Management Registry Template to develop and maintain the registry for your organization.
label: BODY

text: The details of each data management activity can also be visualized in a data management diagram. A diagram
label: BODY

text: offers a visual understanding of an activity and can help identify gaps in data sharing, infrastructure or guidance.
label: BODY

text: Use the Data Management Diagram Template to develop the diagram. The organization-level registry and
label: BODY

text: diagrams serve as the basis for step two described below.
label: BODY

text: The data management diagram below shows the steps of a hypothetical Multi-Sector Needs Assessment (MSNA).
label: BODY

text: 1. Two NGOs collect data from affected people after obtaining consent using the MSNA Informed Consent Form.
label: BODY

text: The NGOs store the data locally on servers in their offices in line with the MSNA Terms of Reference (ToR) and
label: BODY

text: 2. The NGOs share the data with the Assessment Working Group (AWG), which consists of two UN entities and an
label: BODY

text: International Organization. The AWG compiles the data and stores it in the cloud.
label: BODY

text: 3. The AWG shares disaggregated data with the clusters for analysis, which the clusters share back with the AWG
label: BODY

text: once complete. The AWG also shares aggregated data with the local government and a donor government in line
label: BODY

text: 4. The AWG synthesizes the clusters’ analysis and publishes a needs assessment report. It also shares the
label: BODY

text: underlying aggregated data on the Humanitarian Data Exchange.
label: BODY

text: DATA MANAGEMENT DIAGRAM: A MULTI-SECTOR NEEDS ASSESSMENT
label: HH1

text: STEP 2: COMPILING REGISTRIES AT THE CLUSTER/SECTOR-LEVEL AND SYSTEM-WIDE
label: HH1

text: The second step to understanding data ecosystems involves sharing the organization-level data management
label: BODY

text: registry and diagrams with relevant clusters/sectors and with the Information Management Working Group (IMWG)
label: BODY

text: or similar coordination group for compilation. This helps identify data gaps and duplication at the cluster/sector-
label: BODY

text: level and system-wide level. It also enables prioritization and strategic decision-making on responsible data
label: BODY

text: Clusters/sector leads should maintain a cluster/sector-level registry of the data management activities led by their
label: BODY

text: members and relevant to their thematic area of focus. For example, a health cluster data management registry
label: BODY

text: might include activities such as disease monitoring, health facility tracking, distribution of medical supplies. The
label: BODY

text: cluster/sector-level registry should be developed based on the Data Management Registry Template.
label: BODY

text: At the system-wide level, a registry should contain all data management activities in a response, categorized by
label: BODY

text: lead organization and cluster. In most cases, the registry would be compiled by OCHA on behalf of the IMWG, again
label: BODY

text: using the Data Management Registry Template.
label: BODY

text: Registries should be shared publicly to ensure transparency around data management activities.2 In some response
label: BODY

text: environments — notably in conflict settings — the fact that a given data management activity is taking place or
label: BODY

text: specific details about the activity may need to be kept confidential. Any risk associated with sharing the registry
label: BODY

text: should be considered by the lead organization for the activity and in consultation with the relevant cluster/sector
label: BODY

text: The third step is developing data ecosystem maps. A data ecosystem map is a visualization of the various ways
label: BODY

text: that data flows between and among actors in multiple data management activities. OCHA should develop a data
label: BODY

text: ecosystem map at the system-wide level, in consultation with the IMWG and ICCG.
label: BODY

text: Given the complexity of data ecosystems, it may be best to use a white-board or flip chart to sketch out the priority
label: BODY

text: data management activities in your response. If useful, you can then create a digital version using the visualization
label: BODY

text: tools and software designed for this purpose.3 Some details may be excluded to reduce complexity and improve the
label: BODY

text: legibility of the data ecosystem map.
label: BODY

text: The data ecosystem map below represents a data ecosystem in which four hypothetical data management activities
label: BODY

text: are taking place. These include a mobility tracking activity, a needs assessment, internal displacement tracking, and
label: BODY

text: response monitoring. Visualizing these data management activities together helps gain a quick understanding of
label: BODY

text: the actors involved in data management across the response, how data flows between those actors and where there
label: BODY

text: is room for improving the data ecosystem.
label: BODY

text: 2  For example OCHA’s 2021 Assessment Registry for Palestine.
label: BODY

text: 3  Tools include the Open Data Institute Data Ecosystem Mapping tool, the Protection Information Management Training Resource Pack (see package 4 from
label: BODY

text: page 163) or the template provided in Annex D of the IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action. Microsoft Visio is a suitable
label: BODY

text: tool to visualize data ecosystem maps. Free online tools should be used with caution given data security risks.
label: BODY

text: POPULATION, ASSESSMENT, INTERNAL DISPLACEMENT & RESPONSE MONITORING
label: HH1

text: Data ecosystem maps should be completed and updated annually by OCHA in consultation with the IMWG and ICCG.
label: BODY

text: They can be shared publicly unless  they contain data management activities that should be kept confidential. They
label: BODY

text: should also be shared with the Humanitarian Country Team for reference.
label: BODY

text: The development of data management registries, diagrams and data ecosystem maps improves the transparency
label: BODY

text: of data management in humanitarian response. Following the three steps presented in this tip sheet can lead to
label: BODY

text: a better understanding of the actors, data flows and opportunities for improving data management across a data
label: BODY

text: ecosystem. The OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data is available for advisory support to offices and organizations
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data ('the Center'),  together with key partners, is publishing a series of guidance notes
label: BODY

text: and tip sheets on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2022 and 2023. The guidance note series
label: BODY

text: continues work initiated in 2019 and 2020. It also complements the Inter-Agency Standing Committee Operational
label: BODY

text: Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action and the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines,
label: BODY

text: which were published in February 2021 and October 2021 respectively. Through the series, the Centre aims
label: BODY

text: to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data responsibility in practice.
label: BODY

text: The guidance notes and tip sheets published in 2022-2023 have been made possible with the support of the
label: BODY
